commit.message: Relicensing to the Simplified BSD License.

Copy/Remove calls are no longer using shutil

Bedrock Linux uses FUSE in order to divide
their stratus. For whatever reason, shutil
is freaking out when attempting to recursively
copy a directory that is a directory yet complains
that it's a directory -_-. Switching the implementation
of all of our copy and remove commands to be standard
UNIX processes (cp, rm) to do our operations.

Tested for OpenZFS 2.0.0-rc1

- Allows compressed kernel modules to be copied
  into the initramfs.

- If you had a statically compiled binary (i.e busybox),
  you would get a benign error message when attempting to
  detect its dependencies ("Not a dynamic executable").
  This message is now not shown for statically linked binaries.

- The following binary are now optionally copied if detected
  (from OpenZFS 2.0.0-rc1 and maybe 0.8.X as well):

    - /bin/raidz_test
    - /bin/zgenhostid
    - /bin/zvol_wait
    - /sbin/zstream
    - /sbin/zfs_ids_to_path
-v/--version will now display the application version
Fixed a bug where backslashes in passwords were not being escaped
The initramfs will now test and block until the correct decryption key is provided.
[18] Don't copy entire /lib/udev directory (Reduce udev file usage)
Minor styling fixes

Native ZFS Encryption Implemented. LUKS Removed!

General Changes

- Native ZFS encryption with passphrases has been implemented,
  and thus LUKS support has been completely removed. For users
  that are using bliss-initramfs w/ LUKS, please stay on version
  8.1.0 until you migrate over to Native ZFS encryption.

- The 'basic' option has been removed as well and thus bliss-initramfs
  only generates a ZFS initramfs (Nobody really used the 'basic' option),
  and if anything there are plenty of initramfs that support this use case.
  Please migrate to another initramfs for this type of basic functionality.

- Triggers have been removed since it's only a ZFS initramfs. Thus you can
  remove the 'triggers' parameter from your kernel parameter line.

- The interactive menu has been removed. Only command line parameters
  will be accepted.

- The "-f/--features" flag has been removed since it's no longer needed.

- Updated the documentation and converted the README-MORE and USAGE into Markdown.

Bug Fixes

- Fixed a bug where the "options" kernel param was not being
  passed into the mounting of zfs datasets.

More Refinements and Features

- Moved the 'default-settings.json' file into the 'files' directory.

- If the "/etc/bliss-initramfs/settings.json" file (or the specified file)
  is missing, we will fall back to the 'files/default-settings.json'.

- The following LUKS2 header related warning has been fixed:

  "WARNING: Locking directory /run/cryptsetup is missing!"

  https://lists.debian.org/debian-boot/2019/02/msg00100.html

- The initramfs will once again display the top-level modules that will be copied.
  This increases visibility if you happen to use the wrong configuration file
  that doesn't have the modules you need. (The module dependencies will not
  be displayed to reduce spam).

The argument parser has been completely rewritten.

- The argument parser has been completely rewritten and is
  now using 'argparse'.

- You can now use the following arguments in the cli:

  -c, --config   - Path to the settings.json. (i.e: /home/jon/settings.json)
  -f, --features - Comma delimited list of features you want [Available: zfs, luks, basic]. (i.e: zfs,luks).
  -k, --kernel   - The name of the kernel you are building the initramfs for. (i.e: 4.14.170-FC.01)

udevd provider simplification in json

- The udevd provider only needs to be changed once in
  the json file if it defers.
- The copying of zpios manual page has been removed since
  it has been obsolete for a while (and I missed removing it
  a while ago).
Minor styling change

JSON Configuration Support and More

- JSON Configuration Support

bliss initramfs finally has json configuration support.
What this means is that instead of you having to manually
edit the bliss-initramfs specific python hook files to
make your changes (adding module/firmware preferences, etc),
you can now simply modify the /etc/bliss-initramfs/settings.json
file. This means that whenever you update bliss-initramfs, Gentoo's
CONFIG_PROTECT will automatically kick in and allow you to safely
merge any configuration changes with the ones you have locally.

I've also exposed many other settings that may not have been exposed.
Not all settings/variables are exposed since some of them are for
internal use only. If a need arises that we need to expose more,
we can do so.

- Support for copying everything under a specific firmware directory

Before we would only be able to copy either specific firmware files,
or all of the firmware folders. Now we have the option to specify
what firmware folders we want to copy. The benefit of this is that
it still allows us to have a small initramfs, but without having this
all or nothing approach.

- As part of the of the centralization of settings into the settings.json
  file, the autodetection of paths for where your udev provider is located,
  is no more. For people that are not using systemd, you'll have to tweak
  your settings.json so that you can update the path for "/lib/systemd/systemd-udev"
  in the base -> files and also base -> udevPath variables accordingly.

- If copying firmware is enabled, but no files/directories are specified,
  you will no longer get a warning saying that these variables are empty.

- Other styling and documentation changes/updates are included
Unofficially bumping version to 8.1.0 to differentiate current master from release
Added 'beautysh' and beautified the 'init' script
adding poetry and black to the project

Improved "vaultname" derivation.

When no `enc_targets` are provided, include the basename of the raw
volume when creating the name for the unlocked LUKS volume.  This aids
in identifying which LUKS volume came from which physical volume.

Fix ParseByOption.

An apparent copypasta mistake broke the "*" case of this function.

Lots of Goodies!

General Changes
- Codebase has been blackend (19.3b0)
- Copyright notices updated to 2020
- Removed RAID/LVM support
  - bliss-initramfs was always about ZFS, so now it is going back to those
    roots explicitly and only ZFS, LUKS, and a Basic initramfs are supported.
- Base Python required version is now 3.6+ (string interpolation usage)
- Updated README and other documentation
- Removed 'zpios' from initramfs optional files since it's been removed from
  upstream. It used to be for upstream's legacy test architecture.

Internal Changes
- PrintAvailableDrives will now show everything in the root of /dev rather than
  just /dev/[sv]d*. This allows nvme drives and anything else in that dir in the
  future to be properly displayed.

- Refactored/DRY-ed duplicate code for creating library links.

- 'zdb' is no longer a required dependency (it's now optional).

- The generator will no longer have trigger activations being 'sedded' in the initramfs.

  The existing information given by the user in the 'triggers' line is all that is needed.

  This was originally done as a safety feature so that people can't try to run code
  when the code would fail since the dependencies wouldn't have been included in the
  initramfs due to the user not wanting them. However, this is pretty much a useless
  check since the user can still add whatever they want to the 'triggers' line and it
  would still fail. I wanted to do this primarily to remove the need to 'sed' lines
  into the initramfs, which would use hardcoded number lines (Since the code needs to
  know the line to sed). This would lead to chances for me to screw up if I shifted
  the /init file in some way that the line numbers would be out of sync.

- "Addons.py" has been renamed to "Modules.py"

- Modules will now always be loaded if there are any declared.

  Normally the code will only load modules if you are using zfs or if you have
  added any modules into the Modules hook. This is pretty strict and not
  necessary. The code should just automatically load anything in the list (which
  also includes there not being anything in the list!)

- Module and Version info are now loaded from files as well on boot.

  This was also done to eliminate the need to 'sed' the /init file. With this,
  all 'sedding' has been removed and the modules and versions are dumped into
  the /modules.bliss and /version.bliss files in the initramfs. The initramfs
  can then load those up when the system boots.

- Added /dev/mapper to potential directories for loading pool from during
  auto-detection/refresh

- Silencing loading keymap errors (It seems most of the keys are probably
  loading fine, but there may be some keys that violate some type of rule,
  even if dumped and ran with the same tools on the same system).

- Rescue shell switched from bash to busybox's sh in order to have a controlling
  terminal. The initramfs itself will still use bash for running the init script
  itself though. Only the rescue shell is changing. The bash eye candy files for
  the rescue file have also been removed. This is also a bug fix solution since
  before, typing inside the rescue shell environment and then deleting would
  cause the cursor to continue forward, and things would get weird.

Bug Fixes

- Fixed an issue where the system would fail to boot in the situation that you
  had a pool imported in the live system, and then when you rebooted, if that
  pool was not able to be imported (alongside all of the other pools in the
  cache file), it would fail, even though the root pool was technically
  available to be imported and for boot to proceed. Now the initramfs will only
  load the pool where your root system is located, and still use the cachefile
  correctly. Late userspace should be in charge of loading up the rest of the
  non-essential pools and datasets, not the initramfs (i.e root pool is
  necessary, but not necessarily 'backup' pool, etc).

- Fixed a bug where inputting an option other than what the feature list
  provided yielded a KeyError, rather than cleanly displaying an error message.
resuming development, removing message
merging readme conflicts

Relicensed to Apache License 2.0, and bug fix.

- Relicensed to Apache License 2.0
- Fixed a bug where the line to substitute for "useRaidLine" in
  the Variables.py was incorrect.
adding deprecation message and updating readme style to markdown
Relicensing to GPLv3+
Modules are in Addon.py, not addon.sh.

The temporary directory will now be a directory in the current dir.

- The directory that bliss-initramfs uses to perform it's operations
  while building the initramfs will now be a random directory created
  in the current working directory (Format: bi-[RANDOM_NUMBER]), rather
  than using a directory in /tmp. The reason for this change is that a
  user may have mounted their /tmp dir with "noexec" which would prevent
  any execution from occuring in /tmp. This would cause some of the
  bliss-initramfs operations to fail.

- Chroot symlinks will use -f when being created as well in order to
  avoid benign "already exists" messages (Which seem to
  non-deterministically occur). Should be safe since all of these symlinks
  are being created from within the initramfs environment thus it should
  have no impact on the live system.

The temporary directory will now be a directory in the current dir.

- The directory that bliss-initramfs uses to perform it's operations
  while building the initramfs will now be a random directory created
  in the current working directory (Format: bi-[RANDOM_NUMBER]), rather
  than using a directory in /tmp. The reason for this change is that a
  user may have mounted their /tmp dir with "noexec" which would prevent
  any execution from occuring in /tmp. This would cause some of the
  bliss-initramfs operations to fail.

- Chroot symlinks will use -f when being created as well in order to
  avoid benign "already exists" messages (Which seem to
  non-deterministically occur). Should be safe since all of these symlinks
  are being created from within the initramfs environment thus it should
  have no impact on the live system.

commit.message:
Fixed error where removing a non-empty temporary directory would fail

- Fixed an error that was occuring due to the application attempting to remove
  a directory that wasn't empty. Normally this directory only contained one file
  that we would rename and move to it's appropriate location within the initramfs.
  However due to the recent Gentoo systemd root prefix move (/usr/lib/systemd ->
  /lib/systemd), this directory now contains not only the single file we were expecting
  (systemd-udevd), but also one other file which is a libsystemd-shared-###.so).
  Since this directory may contain more files in the future, this directory will now only
  be removed if it is empty.

- Fixed potential situation where libraries that ended in .so would not
  be symlinked properly to their respective /lib32, /lib64 directories.

- Libraries that existed in /lib (and any of its sub folders) would not be
  symlinked back down to /lib. These links are now created.

Fixed error where removing a non-empty temporary directory would fail

- Fixed an error that was occuring due to the application attempting to remove
  a directory that wasn't empty. Normally this directory only contained one file
  that we would rename and move to it's appropriate location within the initramfs.
  However due to the recent Gentoo systemd root prefix move (/usr/lib/systemd ->
  /lib/systemd), this directory now contains not only the single file we were expecting
  (systemd-udevd), but also one other file which is a libsystemd-shared-###.so).
  Since this directory may contain more files in the future, this directory will now only
  be removed if it is empty.

- Fixed potential situation where libraries that ended in .so would not
  be symlinked properly to their respective /lib32, /lib64 directories.

- Libraries that existed in /lib (and any of its sub folders) would not be
  symlinked back down to /lib. These links are now created.

commit.message:
Removing requirement for gpg-conf.skel file for LUKS option

- Removed the requirement for needing to include the
  "/usr/share/gnupg/gpg-conf.skel" when selecting the LUKS option.
  This was essentially an empty file since it was all commented out.
  The file seems to have been removed from upstream inclusion in
  https://dev.gnupg.org/T3086

Removing requirement for gpg-conf.skel file for LUKS option

- Removed the requirement for needing to include the
  "/usr/share/gnupg/gpg-conf.skel" when selecting the LUKS option.
  This was essentially an empty file since it was all commented out.
  The file seems to have been removed from upstream inclusion in
  https://dev.gnupg.org/T3086
